message_1: Consider the projective variety defined by the homogeneous equation $f(x,y,z) = x^3+y^3+z^3=0$ in projective space $\mathbb{P}^2(\mathbb{C})$. Calculate the dimension of the first cohomology group $H^1(\mathbb{P}^2(\mathbb{C}), \mathcal{O}(3))$, where $\mathcal{O}(3)$ is the line bundle associated to the divisor $3\cdot H$, with $H$ the hyperplane at infinity.
message_2:
To compute the dimension of the first cohomology group $H^1(\mathbb{P}^2(\mathbb{C}), \mathcal{O}(3))$, we can use the fact that the cohomology of the line bundle $\mathcal{O}(n)$ on $\mathbb{P}^2(\mathbb{C})$ is given by the following:

$$
H^i(\mathbb{P}^2(\mathbb{C}), \mathcal{O}(n)) = \begin{cases}
\binom{n+2}{2} & \text{if } i = 0 \text{ and } n \geq 0, \\
0 & \text{if } i = 0 \text{ and } n < 0, \\
0 & \text{if } i > 0 \text{ and } n \geq -i, \\
0 & \text{if } i > 2.
\end{cases}
$$

In our case, we are interested in the first cohomology group $H^1(\mathbb{P}^2(\mathbb{C}), \mathcal{O}(3))$. According to the formula above, since $i = 1$ and $n = 3 \geq -i$, we have:

$$
H^1(\mathbb{P}^2(\mathbb{C}), \mathcal{O}(3)) = 0.
$$

Thus, the dimension of the first cohomology group $H^1(\mathbb{P}^2(\mathbb{C}), \mathcal{O}(3))$ is 0.
